subject: Re: [junit] @Before vs constructor
msgSnippet: I don t share your experience there but people do things differently. But I agree that @After is mostly pointless, I seldomly use it. My advice to people
messageBody:
I don't share your experience there but people do things differently.
But I agree that @After is mostly pointless, I seldomly use it. My
advice to people spending grief to clean up after each test anyway is
to stop doing that.
After all, the next test will be run on a new instance anyway so why
bother to clean instance data?

I totally ignore cleaning up instance state after myself since I know
it's not needed (unless there is something particulary expensive that
I am doing but I cant recall any good example of that at the moment so
I'd consider that rare).
The other case where I might reluctantly use @After is if I have some
shared resources such as file resources that I don't want to have
lying around but I have come to prefer cleaning up in @Before to the
pain of acidentaly forgetting to clean after some test in those cases.

Isolation scores pretty high on my list, at the moment I rely on it
completely. To answer your question about how many tests would break
if the instance was shared I must confess, I have no idea, I assume
too many considering that I spend 0 effort restoring state and I
don't want that extra possibility to consider when tests do break. On
the other hand, If no fixture was ever setup in the constructor or,
more commonly, when the field is declared I'd have to admit that
sharing an instance would probably not be an issue. Tools like PMD
could find those situations by static analisys and a rule could be
added to fail those tests in the build...

So there is a way to convert to shared instances that i would be
comfortable with given some clear benefit of doing so, now what is the
benefit?

/J

On Thu, Oct 23, 2008 at 4:20 PM, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> On Thu, Oct 23, 2008 at 2:20 AM, Joakim Ohlrogge
> <joakim.ohlrogge@...> wrote:
>>
>> I think that there would be some unhappy JUnit users out there if we
>> got one instance shared between all tests in the class. The reason is
>> that JUnit tests have always been isolated an we have come to expect
>> that to be the case. It is quite convenient not to have to worry about
>> restoring state between testruns so that testB can never fail because
>> testA failed to clean after iteself
>
> But if this were the case, @After would be pointless, wouldn't it?
>
> How many of your tests would suddenly break if instances were shared?
>
> In my experience, tests and developers already spend a great deal of
> time cleaning up after themselves, which makes me wonder (as you
> already know) if creating a new instance before each method is worth
> the pain it causes...
>
> --
> Cédric
